string-array.name: wake_early_tips
string-array.item: Take short naps or don’t nap at all. Taking short naps after lunch for a maximum of 15\-30 minutes can boost producvity, but don’t take them too late (such as after 5pm).
Don\'t lie around in bed or snooze your alarm, get up and out of bed when you decide to wake up.
The average adult needs 7\-9 hours of sleep per day
Get comfortable. Create a room that\'s ideal for sleeping. Often, this means cool, dark and quiet. Create an environment that suits you, such as using a fan, room darkening shades, or earplugs.
You may be sleep deprived during the weekdays if you sleep significantly longer on the weekends.
Exercise but not right before bedtime
Avoid having a heavy meal close to bedtime
Establish a \"relax and wind down\" routine. Listen to quiet music, take a hot shower or bath to ease tense muscles and calm your mind
Don\'t dwell on worries and frustrations. Stress prevents sleep. Keep a note pad next to your bed to move things out of your mind onto a \"to do\" list.
Avoid the sleep stealer: caffeine, nicotine, alcohol, and other drugs. Turn off caffeine by later afternoon, as it can affect sleep up to 8 hours before bed time.

string-array.name: sleep_early_tips
string-array.item: Exercise but not right before bedtime
You can find more information on healthy sleeping at http://www.gannett.cornell.edu/topics/sleep.cfm
Avoid having a heavy meal close to bedtime
Avoid bright lights before bed.
Don\’t stare at the clock in your bedroom while trying to fall asleep or when you wake up in the middle of the night, as it can actually increase stress. Turn your clock\’s face away from you.
Keep your curtains/blinds open during the day, and try to move your desk closer to the window to get more sunlight.
The average adult needs 7\-9 hours of sleep per day
Get comfortable. Create a room that\'s ideal for sleeping. Often, this means cool, dark and quiet. Create an environment that suits you, such as using a fan, room darkening shades, or earplugs.
You may be sleep deprived during the weekdays if you sleep significantly longer on the weekends.
Exercise but not right before bedtime
Avoid having a heavy meal close to bedtime
Establish a \"relax and wind down\" routine. Listen to quiet music, take a hot shower or bath to ease tense muscles and calm your mind
Don\'t dwell on worries and frustrations. Stress prevents sleep. Keep a note pad next to your bed to move things out of your mind onto a \"to do\" list.
Avoid the sleep stealer: caffeine, nicotine, alcohol, and other drugs. Turn off caffeine by later afternoon, as it can affect sleep up to 8 hours before bed time.
